case_name: Ramratan, Hansraj and Maniram v. State

facts.text: Bhimsen was murdered on May 8, 1959 at Mandi Pili Bangan shortly before 3 P.m.

anchor.surface_text: It arises out of an incident in which Bhimsen was murdered on May 8, 1959 at Mandi Pili Bangan shortly before 3 P.m.

facts.text: There was bad blood between Ramratan appellant and the members of the family of Bhimsen on account of panchayat elections.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution story briefly was, that there was bad blood between Ramratan appellant and the members of the family of Bhimsen on account of panchayat elections in which they had supported rival candidates.

facts.text: Ramratan appellant was prosecuted under s. 307 IPC and Bhimsen was cited as a prosecution witness.

anchor.surface_text: Another cause for enmity was that some time before the occurrences Ramratan appellant was prosecuted under s. 307 of the Indian Penal Code and Bhimsen was cited as a prosecution witness in that case

facts.text: Bhimsen and his father brought some gram for sale on the night between May 7/8, 1959, to Pili Bangan.

anchor.surface_text: and Ramratan did number like that. Bhimsen and his father brought some gram for sale on the night between May 7/8, 1959, to Pili Bangan.

facts.text: Bhimsen returned to the village to bring more grain and came back at about 10/11 A.M. on May 8, 1959 on his tractor-trolly along with his brother Ram Partap.

anchor.surface_text: Bhimsen returned to the village to bring more grain and came back at about10/11 A.M. on the 8th on his tractor-trolly along with his brother Ram Partap.

facts.text: The gram was stacked in front of Roopram's shop in the mandi.

anchor.surface_text: The gram was to be sold through Roopram and was stacked in front of his shop in the mandi.

facts.text: Ram Partap wandered away leaving his father Jawanaram and brother Bhimsen at the shop.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Partap was apparently number interested in the sale and had wandered away leaving his father Jawanaram and his brother Bhimsen at the shop.

facts.text: Shortly before 3 p.m. on May 8, 1959, while gram was being weighed by Lekhram, three appellants and Moman and Ramsingh came armed with guns.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly before 3 p.m. while the gram was being weighed by Lekhram weighman, the three appellants and two others namely, Moman and Ramsingh came up there armed with ,guns.

facts.text: Ramratan shouted that the enemy should number be allowed to escape as Bhimsen was trying to enter Roopram's shop.

anchor.surface_text: Ramratan shouted that the enemy should number be allowed to escape as Bhimsen was trying to enter the shop of Roopram to save himself on seeing these persons.

facts.text: Ramratan fired at Bhimsen from a distance of about 5 feet, Bhimsen got injured, fell down and died soon after.

anchor.surface_text: Before, however, Bhimsen companyld enter the shop of- Roopram, Ramratan came in between and fired at him from a distance about 5 feet. Bhimsen got injured and fell down and died soon after.

facts.text: Jawanaram raised his hands and asked not to kill Bhimsen but Hansraj fired at him causing wound on left hand with compound fracture.

anchor.surface_text: Jawanaram raised his hands and asked the assailants number to kill Bhimsen but Hansraj appellant fired at him causing a wound on his left hand,. which resulted in a companypound fracture.

facts.text: Maniram fired at Jawanaram but he dropped and pellets hit Lekhram who was standing behind.

anchor.surface_text: Maniram also fired at. Jawanaram but he dropped on the ground and pellets hit Lekhram weighman who was standing behind Jawanaram.

facts.text: All assailants ran away after the incident.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter all the assailants ran away.

facts.text: Jawanaram told Roopram the names of the five assailants and asked him to send telegram to police station Suratgarh.

anchor.surface_text: Jawanaram asked him to send telegram to police station Suratgarh and told him the names of the five assailants.

facts.text: Jawanaram made report Ex. P-1 to Ramsingh constable shortly after incident.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon Jawanaram made a report Ex. P- 1 to Ramsingh then and there.

facts.text: Jawanaram's injuries examined at hospital at 3:30 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: After the report had been recorded, Jawanaram was sent to the hospital where his injuries were examined at 3-30 P.m.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted three appellants, acquitted two others.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the three appellants and two others who have been acquitted by the Sessions Judge were prosecuted for this murder.

facts.text: Sessions Judge sentenced Ramratan to death, others to life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: sentencing Ramratan to death and the other two to imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court dismissed appeal and confirmed death sentence on Oct 31, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 31, 1960, of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Criminal Appeal No. 290 of 1960 and D. B, Criminal Murder Reference No 7 of 1960.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment of the Rajasthan High Court.

facts.text: Appellants denied committing the offence and claimed implication due to enmity.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellants was that they had number companymitted this offence and that they had been implicated on account of enmity

facts.text: Court accepted evidence of Jawanaram identifying the three appellants as assailants.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court in accepting the statement of Roopram that Jawanaram had immediately named the five persons who had attacked Bhimsen, Lekhram and himself.

facts.text: Roopram's statement corroborates Jawanaram under s.157 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court therefore upheld the companyviction on the evidence of Jawanaram companyroborated as it was by the evidence of Roopram.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on September 13, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: K. Kapur and T. M. Sen, for the respondent 1961. September. 13. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-
Appeal by special leave from the judgment
under s. 307 of the Indian Penal Code and Bhimsen was cited as a prosecution witness in that case
It arises out of an incident in which Bhimsen was murdered on May 8, 1959 at Mandi Pili Bangan shortly before 3 P.m.
under s. 157 of the Indian Evidence Act, as Jawanaram had number said in his statement in Court

concepts.interpretation: Corroboration does not require the witness to state in court that they made the prior statement; the prior statement relating to the same fact made at or about the time can be proved by the person who heard it.
concepts.unlisted_description: Corroboration by prior statement of witness

anchor.surface_text: under s. 6 as well as under s. 157 of the Evidence Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Corroboration by prior statement of witness

anchor.surface_text: admissible under s. 6 as well as under s. 157

concepts.unlisted_description: Facts forming part of res gestae

anchor.surface_text: either under s. 6 or under s. 157 of the Indian Evidence Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Corroboration by prior statement of witness

anchor.surface_text: Section 157 is in these terms- ,In order to corroborate the testimony of a witness,

concepts.unlisted_description: Corroboration by prior statement of witness

concepts.interpretation: Courts can rely on solitary witness testimony unless statute requires corroboration or prudence demands it based on facts of case.
concepts.unlisted_description: Principle allowing conviction on uncorroborated testimony of solitary eyewitness

anchor.surface_text: He however, gave the benefit of doubt to the other two assailants and acquitted them.

concepts.unlisted_description: Accused entitled to benefit where reasonable doubt exists

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon Jawanaram made a report Ex. P- 1 to Ramsingh then and there.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants applied to this Court for special leave which was granted

issues.text: whether the statement of Roopram to the effect that Jawanaram told him immediately after the incident, when he came out of his shop that the appellants and two others were responsible for the murder of Bhimsen and the injuries to Lekhram and himself, is admissible, either under s. 6 or under s. 157 of the Indian Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: The first question therefore that arises in the appeal is whether the statement of Roopram to the effect that Jawanaram told him immediately after the incident, when he came out of his shop that the appellants and two others were responsible for the murder of Bhimsen and the injuries to Lekhram and himself, is admissible, ei

issues.text: whether, under s. 157 of the Evidence Act, the witness to be corroborated must say in his testimony in court that he had made the former statement to the corroborating person before the corroborating evidence is admissible

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellants in this connection relies on Mt. Misri v. Emperor, and Nazar Singh v. The State which support him and lay down that unless the witness to be corroborated says in his statement in court that he had told certain things immediately after the incident to another person, that other person cannot give evidence and say that the witness had told him certain things immediately after the incident. The argument is that the corroboration that is envisaged by s. 157 is of the statement of the witness in court that he had told certain things to the person corroborating the witness's statement, and if the witness did not say in court that he had told certain things to that person, that person cannot state that the witness had told him certain things immediately after the incident and thus corroborate him.

issues.text: whether the solitary testimony of Jawanaram is sufficient to connect the appellants with the crime and sustain their conviction in the circumstances of the case

arguments.claim: The statement of Roopram that Jawanaram named the assailants immediately after the incident is inadmissible under s. 157 Evidence Act to corroborate Jawanaram because Jawanaram did not say in court that he made that statement to Roopram

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellants in this connection relies on Mt. Misri v. Emperor, and Nazar Singh v. The State which support him and lay down that unless the witness to be corroborated says in his statement in court that be, had told certain things immediately after the incident to another person, that other person cannot give evidence and say that the witness bad told him certain things immediately after the incident.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.157 requires only prior statement relating to same fact at/about time of fact; no need for witness to testify to having made it; overrules cited precedents

arguments.claim: Roopram's statement inadmissible under s.6 Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: The first question therefore that arises in the appeal is whether the statement of Roopram to the effect that Jawanaram told him immediately after the incident, when he came out of his shop that the appellants and two others were responsible for the murder of Bhimsen and the injuries to Lekhram and himself, is admissible, ei

arguments.claim: Solitary uncorroborated testimony of Jawanaram insufficient to convict in circumstances
arguments.court_reasoning: Corroborated by Roopram under s.157; even solitary reliable witness sufficient per Vadivelu Thevar unless prudence demands otherwise; both lower courts accepted

arguments.claim: Jawanaram unreliable because introduced Ram Partap in FIR though not present till 6pm
arguments.court_reasoning: Ram Partap arrived 10/11am per evidence; mentioned in FIR at 3pm; inquest note doesn't contradict

arguments.claim: FIR Ex.P-1 not made at 3pm but up to 6pm, making Jawanaram unreliable
arguments.court_reasoning: Hospital at 3:30pm implies prior police contact; Ram Singh constable reliable; Sessions Judge wrong not to call outpost diary

arguments.claim: Jawanaram unreliable as named 5 assailants but 2 acquitted
arguments.court_reasoning: Benefit of doubt to inactive 2; doesn't falsify re 3 convicted

arguments.claim: Appellants did not commit offence; implicated due to enmity

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellants was that they had not committed this offence and that they had been implicated on account of enmity

arguments.court_reasoning: Jawanaram reliable, corroborated; lower courts accepted

Mt. Misri and Nazar Singh wrongly decided; s.157 doesn't require witness to depose to prior statement

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Sind and Pepsu cases were wrongly decided.

arguments.claim: Solitary witness testimony sufficient unless statute or prudence requires corroboration

arguments.claim: Roopram statement not usable under s.157 as Jawanaram didn't say he told Roopram

anchor.surface_text: As to Roopram he held that his statement that Jawanaram had told him the names of the assailants immediately after the incident was over when he came out of his shop could not be used as corroboration of the statement of Jawanaram under s. 157 of the Indian Evidence Act, as Jawanaram had not said in his statement in Court that he had told Roopram the names of the five assailants
He was also doubtful whether the report Ex. P-1 was recorded at 3 P.m. and thought that it might have been recorded any time up to 6 P.m.

arguments.court_reasoning: Hospital timing and constable evidence confirm ~3pm

arguments.claim: Roopram statement admissible under s.6 and s.157

anchor.surface_text: The High Court thought that this statement of Roopram was admissible under s. 6 as well as under s. 157 of the Evidence Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed on s.157, didn't address s.6

arguments.claim: Ram Partap not present till incident over

anchor.surface_text: He did not rely on the statement of-Ram Partap as he was of the view that Ram Partap did not arrive in the Mandi till about 6 P.m.

holdings.text: There is nothing in s. 157 which requires that before the corroborating witness deposes to the former statement the witness to be corroborated must also say in his testimony in court that he had made that former statement to the witness who is corroborating him.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in s. 157 which requires that before the corroborating witness deposes to the former statement the witness to be corroborated must also say in his testimony in court that he had made that former statement to the witness who is corroborating him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual reading of s.157 requires only (1) court testimony on fact, (2) prior statement on same fact at relevant time; no additional requirement for witness to confirm prior statement.

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that the Sind and Pepsu cases were wrongly decided.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Sind and Pepsu cases were wrongly decided.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior cases misinterpreted s.157 by adding non-textual requirement; contradicted by clear words of section.

holdings.text: Roopram's evidence that Jawanaram had made such a statement would be admissible under s. 157 in corroboration of Jawanaram's testimony as to the fact that five persons had attacked Bhimsen and others.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s.157 interpretation to facts: Jawanaram testified to identities; prior naming to Roopram immediate post-incident proved by Roopram.

holdings.text: We agree with the High Court in accepting the statement of Roopram that Jawanaram had immediately named the five persons who had attacked Bhimsen, Lekhram and himself.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court in accepting the statement of Roopram that Jawanaram had immediately named the five persons who had attacked Bhimsen, Lekhram and himself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Roopram independent witness; High Court acceptance affirmed; corroborates identification.

holdings.text: As a general rule a court may act on the testimony of a single witness, though uncorroborated. ... the question whether corroboration ... must depend upon facts and circumstances of each case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Vadivelu Thevar: no corroboration required absent statute/prudence; distinguishes Vemireddy as accomplice-analogous context inapplicable.

holdings.text: In the circumstances when the evidence of Jawanaram has been accepted by both the courts, with or without corroboration, we see no reason to disagree with the conclusion of the two courts as to the value of Jawanaram's evidence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Both lower courts accepted after scrutiny; specific attacks (FIR timing, Ram Partap, acquittal of 2) rejected on evidence (hospital time, constable, benefit of doubt).

holdings.text: In the circumstances we are of opinion that the appellants have been rightly convicted.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Jawanaram reliable and corroborated under s.157 by Roopram; incident/identities proved.

holdings.text: We agree with the High Court that there are no extenuating circumstances which would justify the reduction of sentence of death passed on Ramratan.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ramratan leader, direct enmity, fired fatal shot at Bhimsen.

precedents.citation: Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy v. The State of Hyderabad 1

anchor.surface_text: As to the second point, namely, that we should number accept the solitary testimony of Jawanaram in the circumstances of this case, learned companynsclrelies on Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy v. The State of Hyderabad  1 . In that case there was the solitary testimony of one witness and it was urged that he was an accomplice. This Court hold that he was number an accomplice but remarked that we would still want companyroboration on material particulars in this particular case

precedents.case_name: Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy v The State of Hyderabad
precedents.cited_proposition: Solitary testimony of a witness in a position somewhat analogous to an accomplice requires corroboration on material particulars.
precedents.cited_holding: we would still want corroboration on material particulars in this particular case, as he is the only witness to the crime and as it would be unsafe to hang four people on his sole testimony unless we feel convinced that he is speaking the truth.

precedents.citation: Vadivelu Thevar v. The State of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: .rho case of such a solitary witness was companysidered by this Court in Vadivelu Thevar v. The State of Madras  1  and after referring to the earlier case it was held that as a general rule a companyrt may act on the testimony of a single witness, though uncorroborated. It was further held that unless companyroboration is insisted upon by statute, companyrts should number insist on companyroboration except in cages where the nature of the testimony of the single witness itself requires as a rule of prudence, that companyroboration should be insisted upon

precedents.case_name: Vadivelu Thevar v The State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: A court may act on the testimony of a single witness though uncorroborated unless prudence requires corroboration depending on facts and circumstances.
precedents.cited_holding: as a general rule a court may act on the testimony of a single witness, though uncorroborated... the question whether corroboration... must depend upon facts and circumstances of each case.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the two courts below were right in relying on Jawanaram. His evidence is corroborated undoubtedly by other witnesses to the extent that the incident did take place at the shop of Roopram his statement that the three appellants and two others were the assailants is corroborated by his former statement made immediately after the incident was over and deposed to by Roopram. In the circumstances we are of opinion that the appellants have been rightly convicted.

outcome.relief_summary: Convictions of appellants Ramratan, Maniram and Hansraj upheld under murder charge; sentence of death confirmed for Ramratan; life imprisonment confirmed for Maniram and Hansraj

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in s. 157 which requires that before the corroborating witness deposes to the former statement the witness to be corroborated must also say in his testimony in court that he had made that former statement to the witness who is corroborating him.

We are therefore of opinion that the two courts below were right in relying on Jawanaram. His evidence is corroborated undoubtedly by other witnesses to the extent that the incident did take place at the shop of Roopram his statement that the three appellants and two others were the assailants is corroborated by his former statement made immediately after the incident was over and deposed to by Roopram. In the circumstances we are of opinion that the appellants have been rightly convicted.
We are therefore of opinion that the Sind and Pepsu cases were wrongly decided.
